revision.comment: /* Un-Cabaret */the work's name is "The New York Times" using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox comedian |name=Beth Lapides |birth_date= |birth_place=[[United States]] |medium=Stand-up comedy, television, film }}
'''Beth Lapides''' ({{IPAc-en|l|ə|ˈ|p|iː|d|ʌ|s}}; {{respell|lə|PEE|dəs}}) is an entertainer, writer, and comedian.<ref>[http://www2.uclaextension.edu/writers/instructors.php?recordID=349 UCLA Extension Writers program, instructor biography] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705230158/http://www2.uclaextension.edu/writers/instructors.php?recordID=349 |date=July 5, 2010 }}</ref>
==Art== Lapides began her career as a visual and performance artist in New York.<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/pss/1145599 Amy C. Ward, "Beth Lapides' ''A Good American Novel'' at P.S. 122", The Drama Review, spring 1985, pp. 41-44, available at jstor.org (fee required for full article)]</ref> She continues to exhibit in group shows.
==Un-Cabaret== By 1990 Lapides and her partner and husband Greg Miller had moved to Los Angeles. In 1993 they created ''[[Un-Cabaret]]'', a live show that became an important venue for the Los Angeles "[[alternative comedy]]" movement.<ref>Lisa Rosen, [http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-un-cabaret-20120305,0,5986877.story "Comedy and music fill the bill at revived Un-Cabaret"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', March 5, 2012.</ref><ref name="Rosen">Lisa Rosen, [http://articles.latimes.com/2007/may/17/news/wk-uncabaret17 " Good, honest humor: At Un-Cabaret, there's no joking around, just personal truths."] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', May 17, 2007.</ref><ref name="Weinraub">Bernard Weinraub, [https://www.nytimes.com/2001/03/05/arts/tired-of-the-same-old-jokes-so-is-this-festival.html "Tired of the Same Old Jokes? So Is This Festival"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', March 5, 2001.</ref> Notable shows that emerged from the Un-Cabaret included [[Julia Sweeney]]'s ''God Said, 'Ha!'' and [[Laura Kightlinger]]'s book ''Quick Shots of False Hope''.<ref name=Rosen/> Spin-off productions from the Un-Cabaret have included ''Say the Word'', a story-telling show; ''The Other Network'', a show featuring unaired pilots, and the Un-Cab Lab, a student workshop.<ref name="Rosen"/>
==Did I Wake You?== Lapides's first book ''Did I Wake You?--Haikus for Modern Living'' was published in 2007.<ref name="Rosen"/>
==Theatre== Lapides has created several one-person shows and performance pieces, including a satirical 1992 campaign to be elected [[First Lady]],<ref>Judith Michaelson, [http://articles.latimes.com/1992-03-21/entertainment/ca-4023_1_beth-lapides " Beth Lapides: The Joke's on Voters. Comedy: Performance artist kicks off shtick to make America's top female position elective."], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', March 21, 1992.</ref><ref>Elizabeth Gleick, [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20108845,00.html "Loose Cannons"], ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', October 19, 1992.</ref> a 2007 show based on her book of haiku,<ref name="Rosen"/> and a recent production entitled ''100% Happy 88% of the Time''.<ref>[http://www.boston.com/ae/events/articles/2010/07/22/nightlife_the_week_ahead/ "100& Happy 88% of the Time"], ''[[Boston Globe]], July 22, 2010.</ref>
==Filmography== Lapides appeared in the famous "Sex and the City" TV series as a performance artist who doesn't speak or eat in the "One" episode (2003).
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.bethlapides.com Official Website] *[http://www.uncabaret.com Un-Cabaret]
